The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility

HAZARD COMMUNICATION PROGRAM
CITY OF EL MIRAGE PUBLIC WORKS

I.    PURPOSE

    The purpose of the Written Hazard Communication program is to ensure     that:

1.    Hazardous substances present in the work place are properly identified and labeled.

2.    Employees have access to information on the hazards of these substances.

3.    Employees are provided with information on how to prevent injuries or illnesses due to exposure to these substances.

4.    Identify by job title the responsibility for maintaining the program, the MSDS sheets, conduct training, etc. 

5.    To comply with the OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.1200, pertaining to Hazard Communication.

Note:  This program will be available to all employees for review and a copy will be located in the following area(s):

Location:
1. Water Division, 12000 W Peoria Avenue
2. Wastewater Division, 12000 W Peoria Avenue
3. Operations Division, 12000 W Peoria Avenue
4. Street and Parks Division, 12000 W Peoria Avenue    
5. Public Works Office,12145 N. W. Grand Avenue 

II.    AUTHORITY AND REFERENCE

Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.1200

Facility and the regulated substances handled
  
The facility is a tertiary wastewater treatment facility (WWTF) called Sequential Batch Reactors (SBRs) employing the activated sludge process.  The SBR facility consists of the following treatment Units:  Parshall flume (12 inch), automated bar screens, wet well, pump station, fine screen and grit removal unit, equalization basin, four activated sludge basins (SBRs) with nitrification and denitrification during a fill, mix, settle and decant cycle.  
The effluent from the supernate decant of SBRs is discharged into a surge tank, thru the filters (cloth Aqua Disk), thru UV system, to reuse pump station down to reuse pond for further disinfection by chlorine gas.  There are two (2) one ton gas cylinders of chlorine on site at the disinfection statio

n.  One cylinder is in use and the other cylinder is the replacement.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

PREVENTION PROGRAM SUMMARY
40 CFR PART 68 SUBPART D

Process Safety Information (68.65 CFR)
Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS)
Process Hazard Analysis (68.67 CFR)
?What if? 40 CFR 68.67(b)1: The installation of the cylinders is not followed in the order that is defined in the ?Changing of Cylinders Protocol?  
The consequences of a release are addressed in the Hazardous Communications Training and Chlorine Safety Training.
The training insures that engineering and administrative controls for safety technique guidelines and protocol are followed. 
Operating Procedures (68.69)
Steps for each operating phase are very basic in that the system is shut down completely before and during changing of the cylinders.  All emergency situations, chlorine protocol, safety and health considerations are outlined and followed.
Training (68.71)
Each new employee is trained initial during the first year of employment and refresher training is provided every three years.  All records of training are kept on file at the Human resources Department and the Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Employees are trained to leave the area in case of a leak and call Fire Department and HAZ MAT team.
Mechanical Integrity (68.73)
All employees are trained on the inspection, maintenance and repair.  All Manuals and protocols are available for employees.  There are daily checks of the chlorine cylinders and monthly inspections when the cylinders are changed.  All checks and inspections are documented in the operator?s daily log.  The manufacture replaces all fittings.
Management of Change (68.75)
This basic chlorine facility will be decommissioned in the coming months as a new disinfection system will be installed.  Therefore updating process and operating procedures is not applicable.
Pre-Startup Review (68.77)
There will be no modifications ther

efore this does not apply.
Compliance Audits (68.79)
Compliance audits are preformed by the Superintendent. Due to poor performance an age of system it will be decommissioned in a few months.
Incident investigation (68.81)
No later than 48 hours an investigation would begin. The investigative team would consist of the Fire Chief, Public Works Director, Wastewater Superintendent and Regulatory Coordinator.  Staff involved would also be part of the fact finding team.  The report would have all the elements as required by 40 CFR 68.81(d)1 2 3 4 5.  This report would be turned over to the City Manager and City Council.
Employee participation (68.83)
The staff can present ideas or thoughts to the Wastewater Superintendent.  All pro and cons are addressed.  The rules and protocols are consulted to implement the idea to the Safety Management Plan.
All employees are provided information on facilities and hazardous materials to be in compliance with the Right to Know Laws.
Hot work permits (68.85)
All hot work situations are contracted out and it is up to the contractor to handle hot work permits, fire prevention, fire protection (29 CFR 1910.252(a), and safety precautions. 
Contractors (68.87)
At this time no contractors are used for any repair or maintenance.  However, if a situation would arise the manufacturer of the Chlorine facility would be contacted for contractual work. 

Five-year accident history

There have been no accidents with the chlorine gas in the past 5 or 10 years.

Contact the Public Works Department Monday through Friday from 8 am to 5 pm.  Staff will contact Supervisors and Director, regarding the emergency call, giving as many details as possible.

After hours on call operator will be contacted and the on call operator will contact immediate super visor as soon as possible.

Supervisor/Senior Operator and trained personal will call for assistance if required from the Fire and Police Departments to secure and or evacuate the immediate area if required.  HAZ MAT Team will take over to secure the release.

Response

Planned changes to improve safety
There are 3 departments located at the Wastewater Treatment Facility they are Operations, Drinking Water and Wastewater divisions.  It is up to the Superintendents of each division to keep all of their employees trained on a regular basis.  With the new up and coming disinfection process of liquid bleach there will be training for all of the Wastewater Operators involved with the new unit.
